clinical_study.brief_title: Feasibility Study of Retinal Screening Using the RetinaVue 100 Camera in Outpatient Dialysis Centers
clinical_study.official_title: A Feasibility Study of Retinal Screening Using the RetinaVue 100 Hand- Held (Non-mydriatic) Camera in Outpatient Dialysis Centers

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to look at retinal abnormalities in outpatient renal dialysis patients using the FDA approved RetinaVue 100 hand-held (non-mydriatic) camera.

detailed_description.textblock: There are no studies evaluating (diabetic or non-diabetic) retinopathy in the renal dialysis patient population (~300,000 Americans). Approximately 50% of this population has End-stage Retinal Disease (ESRD) due to diabetes. Dialysis patients are among the most debilitated patients, and thus, have even more barriers to receiving their recommended annual retinal evaluation. The advent of the RetiaVue hand-held retinal camera holds great promise in this population, as dialysis patients access medical care 3 times a week, for several hours at a time at their dialysis clinic.

primary_outcome.measure: Usability of the RetinaVue Hand-Held 100 Camera
primary_outcome.description: Usability survey data to be collected at two different time points by the camera operators. The first survey will be completed at the end of each eye exam asking the camera operator to assess the time and number of attempts to acquire acceptable images, the number of eye exams completed per full battery charge, and patient perceptions of ease of use. The second survey will be completed once per week and contains 11 questions measuring usability as ease of use on a 5-point Likert scale ranging from "Strongly Disagree" (1) to "Strongly Agree" (5).

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of diabetic dialysis subjects having prior retinal screening
Percentage of diabetic dialysis subjects screened at study conclusion
Percent change from baseline in diabetic dialysis subjects screened
Rates of overall retinopathy in a dialysis population

secondary_outcome.description: Participant satisfaction survey data to be collected following the completion of retinal screening. Participants will be assessed on participant satisfaction measures such as comfort of experience, recovery time, and time invested in undergoing procedure vs. traditional screening methods.

arm_group.description: Participants will have a retinal screening completed by study staff using the FDA-approved RetinaVue 100 hand-held camera

intervention.description: Images of the subject's eye will be obtained using the RetinaVue 100 camera and uploaded to a secure network. The study doctor, a board-certified ophthalmologist, will interpret the patient images and return a diagnosis and management plan to the dialysis unit.
